ten_commandments.title: The First Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The First Commandment: Thou shalt have no other gods.
ten_commandments.explanation: This commandment is defined in the Large Catechism as the **chief source and fountainhead** from which all others flow. To have a god is essentially to have something from which the heart expects all good and to which it takes refuge in all distress. It is the **confidence and faith of the heart** alone that make both God and an idol. Martin Luther identifies Mammon, or money and property, as the most common idol in the world, asserting that whatever the heart clings to is truly that person's god. This commandment requires us to **fear, love, and trust in God above all things**, serving as the basis for all human accountability.

questions.question: According to the Large Catechism, what is the 'maker' of a god?
options: A person's good works and rituals
The confidence and faith of the heart
The authority of the church hierarchy
The specific name used in prayer
questions.answer: The confidence and faith of the heart

questions.question: What does Luther identify as the most common idol in the world?
options: Political power
Fame and reputation
Mammon (money and property)
Self-righteousness
questions.answer: Mammon (money and property)

ten_commandments.title: The Second Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Second Commandment: Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord, thy God, in vain.
ten_commandments.explanation: This commandment forbids using God's name to lie, deceive, curse, or practice magic. Positively, it mandates that Christians **call upon God's name in every trouble** and use it for prayer, praise, and thanksgiving. Luther emphasizes that **prayer is a strict duty and obligation** commanded by God, carrying the same weight as the prohibition against murder. The name of God is considered profaned when those who claim to be His children live evil lives or teach false doctrines that misrepresent His Word.

questions.question: What positive action is mandated by the Second Commandment?
options: Observing the Sabbath rest
Giving to the poor regularly
Calling upon God's name in every need
Building grand places of worship
questions.answer: Calling upon God's name in every need

questions.question: How is God's name profaned according to Lutheran teaching?
options: By translating the Bible into common languages
By living an evil life while claiming to be a Christian
By speaking the name of God in public
By failing to pay a full tithe to the church
questions.answer: By living an evil life while claiming to be a Christian

ten_commandments.title: The Third Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Third Commandment: Thou shalt sanctify the holy-day.
ten_commandments.explanation: In Lutheran theology, the literal requirement to rest on the seventh day was given specifically to the Jewish nation and is not legally binding on Christians. However, the moral substance remains: we are to **honor and gladly hear the preaching of God's Word**. The Sabbath is not made holy by the act of resting itself, but by **God's Word**, which Luther calls the 'treasure that sanctifies everything.' Whenever the Word is preached, heard, or pondered, both the person and the day are made holy. Neglecting the public administration of the Word and Sacraments is a violation of this command.

questions.question: What makes the Sabbath day holy according to the Large Catechism?
options: The physical act of resting from labor
The Word of God
The tradition of the ancient fathers
The specific day of the week selected
questions.answer: The Word of God

questions.question: What is the primary duty for a Christian under the Third Commandment?
options: To avoid all forms of commerce on Sunday
To replicate ancient Jewish ceremonies
To willingly hear and learn God's Word
To spend the day in silent isolation
questions.answer: To willingly hear and learn God's Word

ten_commandments.title: The Fourth Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Fourth Commandment: Thou shalt honor thy father and thy mother.
ten_commandments.explanation: God places parenthood in a position of honor second only to Himself. All earthly authority is viewed as **flowing and being propagated from the authority of parents**. This includes 'fathers in blood' (biological parents), 'fathers in office' (civil government), and 'spiritual fathers' (pastors). Parents are charged with bringing up their children in the **fear and knowledge of God** and providing for their education so they can serve society. Honoring parents involves serving and obeying them for God's sake, recognizing them as His representatives.

questions.question: From what source does all earthly authority flow according to Luther?
options: The social contract of citizens
The authority of parents
The military power of the state
The democratic process
questions.answer: The authority of parents

questions.question: What is the 'Table of Duties' in the Small Catechism related to?
options: The various ranks of the clergy
Specific rules for church architecture
How Christians are to govern their conduct in their place in life
The historical timeline of the Reformation
questions.answer: How Christians are to govern their conduct in their place in life

ten_commandments.title: The Fifth Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Fifth Commandment: Thou shalt not kill.
ten_commandments.explanation: This commandment prohibits murder and physical harm, but also targets the roots of violence: **anger, hatred, and bitterness**. Positively, Luther emphasizes that we should **assist and serve our neighbor in every bodily danger or need**. A Christian is called to have a patient and gentle heart, doing good even to those who are enemies. Any harm done to a neighbor, including through the manipulation of laws to damage their well-being, stands condemned under this heading.

questions.question: What is the positive requirement for a Christian regarding their neighbor's life?
options: To ignore their physical needs and focus on their soul
To assist and serve them in every bodily danger or need
To seek legal revenge for every personal wrong
To provide them with worldly wealth above all else
questions.answer: To assist and serve them in every bodily danger or need

questions.question: How can the Fifth Commandment be broken without physical violence?
options: By owning an excessive amount of property
Through anger, hatred, or slandering with the tongue
By choosing a different religious tradition
By missing a single church service
questions.answer: Through anger, hatred, or slandering with the tongue

ten_commandments.title: The Sixth Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Sixth Commandment: Thou shalt not commit adultery.
ten_commandments.explanation: This commandment mandates a **chaste and decent life in words and deeds** and requires that husbands and wives **love and honor each other**. Luther understands marriage as a divine order and mystery that reflects the relationship between Christ and the Church. It forbids not only physical adultery but also **impure thoughts and the destruction of marriage's purpose** through lust. Marriage is held in high esteem because God sanctioned and guarded it as the highest estate for the procreation of children and the stability of society.

questions.question: According to Luther, what biblical 'mystery' does marriage reflect?
options: The mystery of the creation of the stars
The mystery of the relationship between Christ and the Church
The mystery of the origin of human language
The mystery of how to live without any suffering
questions.answer: The mystery of the relationship between Christ and the Church

questions.question: What does this commandment require of husbands and wives?
options: To prioritize their parents over their spouse
To live separately for the sake of higher holiness
To love and honor each other
To focus solely on earthly riches and success
questions.answer: To love and honor each other

ten_commandments.title: The Seventh Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Seventh Commandment: Thou shalt not steal.
ten_commandments.explanation: This commandment protects the rights of ownership and forbids the right acquisition of goods through fraud or dishonest business practices. Luther applies this to **economic ethics**, condemning usury, greed, and 'legal' tricks used to obtain property. He labels those who exploit others under the pretext of right as **'swivel-chair robbers.'** The positive requirement is to **help the neighbor improve and protect his possessions and income**, recognizing private ownership as divinely ordained.

questions.question: What term does Luther use for those who steal using 'legal' tricks or trade?
options: Petty thieves
Swivel-chair robbers
Righteous merchants
Holy monks
questions.answer: Swivel-chair robbers

questions.question: What positive duty does a Christian have toward a neighbor's property?
options: To help the neighbor improve and protect it
To demand that the neighbor share it with all people equally
To ignore it as a temporary worldly matter
To take it if they believe it was acquired unfairly
questions.answer: To help the neighbor improve and protect it

ten_commandments.title: The Eighth Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Eighth Commandment: Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbor.
ten_commandments.explanation: The focus here is on **governing the tongue** and protecting the neighbor's reputation. It forbids lying about, slandering, or betraying others. Christians are commanded to defend their neighbor, speak well of them, and **put the best construction on everything they do**. Luther emphasizes the 'order of the Gospel' from <bible-ref>Matthew 18</bible-ref>, which instructs that a brother's fault should be addressed privately before being made public, using the tongue to cover infirmities rather than expose them.

questions.question: What is the 'best construction' rule in the Eighth Commandment?
options: To build the neighbor a higher quality house
To interpret the neighbor's actions in the kindest possible way
To ignore all laws of evidence in a court of law
To never speak of a neighbor's sin even if it is public
questions.answer: To interpret the neighbor's actions in the kindest possible way

questions.question: How should a Christian first handle a brother's sin according to Matthew 18?
options: Report it immediately to the local authorities
Gossip about it to warn the rest of the congregation
Admonish him privately
Wait for a formal church council to take action
questions.answer: Admonish him privately

ten_commandments.title: The Ninth Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Ninth Commandment: Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's house.
ten_commandments.explanation: This commandment targets **internal desires and 'impure thoughts'** that lead a person to seek what belongs to their neighbor. It specifically addresses seeking to obtain a neighbor's **inheritance or home** through 'wicked cunning' or a 'show of right.' Luther notes that this commandment is addressed especially to the **most pious**, who may not break external laws but still harbor envy or avarice in the heart. It reveals the deep-seated 'evil infection' of human nature that persists even when outward works appear good.

questions.question: What does the Ninth Commandment specifically protect?
options: The neighbor's physical life
The neighbor's wife and servants
The neighbor's inheritance and house
The neighbor's livestock and cattle
questions.answer: The neighbor's inheritance and house

questions.question: To whom does Luther say the commandments against coveting are especially addressed?
options: Known criminals and outlaws
The unbaptized and heathens
The most pious and honest people
Publicans and notorious sinners
questions.answer: The most pious and honest people

ten_commandments.title: The Tenth Commandment
ten_commandments.commandment: The Tenth Commandment: Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's wife, nor his man-servant, nor his maid-servant, nor his cattle, nor anything that is his.
ten_commandments.explanation: The Tenth Commandment focuses on the **alienation or enticement** of the people and creatures that serve the neighbor. It forbids driving away or forcing a neighbor's spouse or workers to leave. Luther emphasizes that we should instead **urge them to stay and do their duty** in the places where God has put them. These final commandments serve as a mirror to show that no one is fully pure in heart, pointing the believer to the need for the forgiveness found in the Gospel.

questions.question: What is the positive requirement regarding a neighbor's workers?
options: To hire them away for a better wage
To set them free from their master immediately
To urge them to stay and diligently do their duty
To ignore their existence entirely
questions.answer: To urge them to stay and diligently do their duty

questions.question: What is the theological function of the Ninth and Tenth Commandments as a whole?
options: To provide a list of rewards for the righteous
To establish the civil code for property disputes
To reveal that the heart is the source of all sin
To allow Christians to judge their neighbors' hearts
questions.answer: To reveal that the heart is the source of all sin

ten_commandments.title: The Close of the Commandments
ten_commandments.explanation: The Ten Commandments are considered the only part of the Law of Moses that is eternal, inscribed on the hearts of all men as natural law. Outside of these commandments, **no work can be good or pleasing to God**, no matter how great it appears to the world. Their primary purpose is to reveal God's wrath against sin, acting as a mirror to show our inability to save ourselves and guiding the 'new man' on the path of good works that are pleasing to God.

apostles_creed.title: The Apostles' Creed - First Article
apostles_creed.explanation: The First Article confesses God as **Father, Almighty, and Maker**. Luther's explanation in the Small Catechism emphasizes a personal realization: **'I believe that God has made me and all creatures.'** This means God has provided not only the soul and body but also every faculty, including **eyes, ears, reason, and senses**, and continues to preserve them daily. The Large Catechism notes that we recognize God as our Father because He provides for us out of **sheer fatherly and divine goodness and mercy**, without any merit or worthiness in us. This article encompasses all temporal goods—clothing, shoes, food, drink, house, and home—and asserts that God **defends us against all danger** and guards us from all evil. Thus, the duty of the Christian is to **thank, praise, serve, and obey Him**.

questions.question: According to the Small Catechism, what is the basis for God providing all that we need?
options: Our consistent obedience to the Law
Our merit and worthiness
Sheer fatherly, divine goodness and mercy
Our regular attendance at the Divine Service
questions.answer: Sheer fatherly, divine goodness and mercy

questions.question: What does the First Article teach about God's ongoing work?
options: He created the world and then stepped back
He still takes care of all His members and senses
He only provides for those who pray for daily bread
He only takes care of the soul, not the body
questions.answer: He still takes care of all His members and senses

apostles_creed.title: The Apostles' Creed - Second Article
apostles_creed.explanation: This article focuses on the person and work of Jesus Christ, whom the Christian confesses as **'my Lord.'** Luther explains that for Christ to be 'Lord' means He is **'my Redeemer'** who has purchased and won us from **all sins, from death, and from the power of the devil.** This redemption was achieved not with gold or silver, but with His **holy, precious blood and His innocent suffering and death.** The purpose of this work is that the believer may **be His own, live under Him in His kingdom, and serve Him** in everlasting righteousness, innocence, and blessedness. The article affirms His two natures—**true God, begotten of the Father from eternity, and true man, born of the Virgin Mary**—and centers the entire Gospel on His resurrection and eternal reign.

questions.question: What does the word 'Lord' essentially mean in Luther's explanation of the Second Article?
options: Ruler of the universe
Redeemer
Taskmaster
Legislator
questions.answer: Redeemer

questions.question: From what three powers has Christ redeemed the believer?
options: Poverty, sickness, and sadness
The Pope, the Turks, and the Jews
Sin, death, and the power of the devil
The Law, the world, and the flesh
questions.answer: Sin, death, and the power of the devil

apostles_creed.title: The Apostles' Creed - Third Article
apostles_creed.explanation: The Third Article treats the work of the **Holy Spirit**, who is the **Sanctifier**. The core of this article is the confession that **'I cannot by my own reason or strength believe in Jesus Christ, my Lord, or come to Him.'** Instead, the Holy Spirit **calls us by the Gospel, enlightens us with His gifts, and sanctifies and keeps us in the true faith.** This work is not done in isolation but through the **holy Christian Church**, which the Spirit calls, gathers, and enlightens on earth. In this Church, the Spirit **daily and richly forgives all my sins and the sins of all believers.** Finally, the Spirit provides eschatological hope, as He will **raise the dead on the Last Day** and give eternal life to all believers in Christ.

questions.question: Why is the work of the Holy Spirit necessary according to the Small Catechism?
options: Because human reason is too weak and strength is lacking to believe
Because God will not save us unless we ask the Spirit
To prove that we are doing good works
To help us understand the deep mysteries of philosophy
questions.answer: Because human reason is too weak and strength is lacking to believe

questions.question: Where does the Holy Spirit daily and richly forgive sins?
options: In the private heart of the individual only
In the holy Christian Church
Only in the future kingdom of glory
Through our own acts of satisfaction
questions.answer: In the holy Christian Church

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - Introduction
lords_prayer.explanation: In the introduction, God **tenderly invites us to believe** that He is our **true Father** and that we are His **true children**. This relationship allows us to approach Him with **all boldness and confidence**, just as beloved children entreat an affectionate father. The Large Catechism notes that we can only call Him Father because Christ, our Advocate, has taught us this and because we have been **baptized into His name** and given the Spirit of adoption.

questions.question: What does the introduction to the Lord's Prayer 'tenderly invite' us to do?
options: Fear the coming judgment
Believe He is our true Father and we are His true children
Follow all the commandments before speaking
Understand the complex nature of the Trinity
questions.answer: Believe He is our true Father and we are His true children

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - First Petition
lords_prayer.explanation: God's name is **holy in itself**, but we pray that it may be **kept holy among us**. This occurs when the **Word of God is taught in its truth and purity** and when we, as children of God, **lead holy lives according to it**. Conversely, anyone who teaches or lives contrary to God's Word **profanes the name of God** among us. The Large Catechism identifies this as the spiritual defense against false teachers and an evil life.

questions.question: How is God's name kept holy among us?
options: By never speaking it aloud
When the Word of God is taught in its truth and purity and we live accordingly
By building large cathedrals in His honor
Only through the performance of the sacraments
questions.answer: When the Word of God is taught in its truth and purity and we live accordingly

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - Second Petition
lords_prayer.explanation: The kingdom of God **comes of itself without our prayer**, but we pray that it may **come to us**. This happens when our heavenly Father **gives us His Holy Spirit**, so that by His grace we **believe His holy Word** and lead godly lives here in time and hereafter in eternity. It is a prayer for the Spirit to reign in our hearts and for the Gospel to be spread throughout the world.

questions.question: What is requested of the Father in the Second Petition?
options: The physical return of Christ immediately
That He give us His Holy Spirit to work grace and faith
The destruction of earthly governments
That we may be given power to rule others
questions.answer: That He give us His Holy Spirit to work grace and faith

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - Third Petition
lords_prayer.explanation: God's **good and gracious will** is done even without our prayer, but we pray that it may be **done among us**. God's will is done when He **breaks and hinders every evil plan and purpose** of the devil, the world, and our sinful nature. It is also done when He **strengthens and keeps us firm in His Word and faith** until we die. We pray against our own will and the devil's will, which seek to block God's name and kingdom.

questions.question: According to the Small Catechism, what does God do to ensure His will is done?
options: He rewards our good works with prosperity
He breaks and hinders the evil plans of the devil and our sinful nature
He forces all people to become Christians
He ignores our sins for a time
questions.answer: He breaks and hinders the evil plans of the devil and our sinful nature

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - Fourth Petition
lords_prayer.explanation: God gives daily bread **even to the wicked** without our prayer, but we pray that He would lead us to **realize this and receive our daily bread with thanksgiving**. Daily bread includes everything that has to do with the **support and needs of the body**, such as food, drink, clothing, house, home, land, animals, money, a devout spouse, obedient children, **upright and faithful rulers, and good government.**

questions.question: What is included in the definition of 'daily bread'?
options: Only spiritual food like the Bible
Only the bread used in the Lord's Supper
Everything that has to do with the support and needs of the body
Only the basic necessities like grain and water
questions.answer: Everything that has to do with the support and needs of the body

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - Fifth Petition
lords_prayer.explanation: In this petition, we pray that our Father in heaven would **not look at our sins** nor deny our prayer because of them. We are unworthy of what we ask, but we pray that He would **give us everything by grace**, for we sin daily and deserve nothing but punishment. The 'as we forgive' part is a **promise and sign**; because God forgives us freely, we will also **heartily forgive and gladly do good** to those who sin against us.

questions.question: Why do we say 'as we forgive' in this petition?
options: To earn God's forgiveness through our own efforts
As a sign that we have received God's free grace and will likewise forgive others
To remind God that we are essentially good people
To demand that our neighbor apologize first
questions.answer: As a sign that we have received God's free grace and will likewise forgive others

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - Sixth Petition
lords_prayer.explanation: God tempts no one, but we pray that He would **guard and keep us** so that the **devil, the world, and our sinful nature** may not deceive us or mislead us into false belief, despair, or other great shame and vice. We pray that even if we are attacked by such temptations, we may **finally overcome and win the victory**.

questions.question: What are the three powers mentioned that seek to mislead the believer into false belief and despair?
options: The Pope, the Turks, and the heretics
The devil, the world, and our sinful nature
Reason, science, and philosophy
Hunger, poverty, and sickness
questions.answer: The devil, the world, and our sinful nature

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - Seventh Petition
lords_prayer.explanation: This is a **summary petition** where we pray that our Father in heaven would **rescue us from every evil of body and soul, possessions and reputation**. We pray that when our **last hour comes**, He would grant us a **blessed end** and graciously take us from this valley of sorrow to Himself in heaven.

questions.question: What is the primary request regarding the 'last hour' in the Seventh Petition?
options: That we may live forever on this earth
That we may be granted a blessed end and taken to heaven
That our possessions be left to our children
That we may avoid all physical pain
questions.answer: That we may be granted a blessed end and taken to heaven

lords_prayer.title: The Lord's Prayer - Conclusion
lords_prayer.explanation: The conclusion provides the **certainty of faith**. We should be **assured that these petitions are acceptable** to our Father in heaven and are heard by Him, for He has commanded us to pray this way and promised to hear us. **'Amen'** means **'Yes, yes, it shall be so.'** It seals the prayer with the confidence that God's promises are true and reliable.

questions.question: What does the word 'Amen' mean in the context of the Lord's Prayer?
options: I hope this comes true
The prayer is now finished
Yes, yes, it shall be so
I will try to be a better person
questions.answer: Yes, yes, it shall be so

sacrament_of_holy_baptism.title: Holy Baptism - Part 1
sacrament_of_holy_baptism.explanation: Baptism is defined in the Small Catechism as **not just plain water**, but water included in **God's command and combined with God's word**. The Large Catechism explains that when the Word of God is added to the element of water, it becomes a **sacrament—a holy, divine thing**. The specific 'Word of God' referred to is the **Great Commission** from <bible-ref>Matthew 28:19</bible-ref>, where Christ commands the church to baptize in the name of the **Father, Son, and Holy Spirit**. Without this divine mandate, the water is no different from water used for cooking or a 'bath-keeper's baptism'.

questions.question: What two things together constitute Baptism according to the Small Catechism?
options: Faith and ritual washing
Water and God's Word
Prayer and sanctified oil
The priest's intention and water
questions.answer: Water and God's Word

questions.question: According to the Large Catechism, what is Baptism called when the Word is separated from the water?
options: An invalid sign
A bath-keeper's baptism
A spiritual washing
A traditional ceremony
questions.answer: A bath-keeper's baptism

sacrament_of_holy_baptism.title: Holy Baptism - Part 2
sacrament_of_holy_baptism.explanation: Baptism is a **true means of grace** that works the **forgiveness of sins, rescues from death and the devil, and gives eternal salvation**. The sources emphasize that these benefits are given to all who believe, as declared in **<bible-ref>Mark 16:16</bible-ref>**. The Large Catechism teaches that to be saved through baptism is to be **delivered from the tyranny of sin, death, and Satan** and to be transferred into the kingdom of Christ to live with Him forever. It is not a human work, but a **treasure God gives and faith receives**.

questions.question: What is the primary power or 'work' of Baptism described in the Small Catechism?
options: To grant membership in a local parish
To symbolise a clean life
To save and deliver from the devil
To remind the parents of their duties
questions.answer: To save and deliver from the devil

questions.question: To whom does Baptism grant eternal salvation?
options: To all who are physically washed
Only to those who are born of Christian parents
To all who believe the words and promises of God
To those who perform enough good works afterwards
questions.answer: To all who believe the words and promises of God

sacrament_of_holy_baptism.title: Holy Baptism - Part 3
sacrament_of_holy_baptism.explanation: The sources state clearly that **'water indeed does not do it'**, but rather the **Word of God** which accompanies the water and the **faith** which trusts that Word. The water is sanctified by the Word to become a **'gracious water of life'** and a **'washing of regeneration'**. Citing <bible-ref>Titus 3:5</bible-ref>, the catechism explains that God saves us through the **renewing of the Holy Spirit**, whom He poured out on us generously through Jesus Christ. The power of the sacrament rests entirely on the **objective promise of God**, which faith then grasps.

questions.question: What biblical passage is used to describe Baptism as the 'washing of regeneration'?
options: John 3:16
Titus 3:5
Romans 12:1
Matthew 5:1
questions.answer: Titus 3:5

questions.question: What role does faith play in the efficacy of the water in Baptism?
options: Faith creates the power in the water
Faith is unnecessary for any benefit
Faith trusts the Word of God in the water
Faith is the physical element of the sacrament
questions.answer: Faith trusts the Word of God in the water

sacrament_of_holy_baptism.title: Holy Baptism - Part 4
sacrament_of_holy_baptism.explanation: Baptizing with water signifies that the **Old Adam in us**, with all sins and evil desires, should be **drowned and die through daily contrition and repentance**. In its place, a **new man should daily emerge and arise** to live before God in righteousness and purity forever. This is based on **<bible-ref>Romans 6:4</bible-ref>** which teaches that we are **buried with Christ by baptism into death** so that we may walk in newness of life. The Large Catechism adds that the Christian life is nothing else than a **daily baptism**, begun once but continuing ever after.

questions.question: According to Romans 6, we are buried with Christ by baptism into what?
options: The Church
The Law
Death
Suffering
questions.answer: Death

questions.question: How often should the 'new man' emerge in the life of a Christian?
options: Once a year during Lent
Only at the moment of physical baptism
Daily
Only when the person feels holy
questions.answer: Daily

confession_and_office_of_the_keys.title: Confession
confession_and_office_of_the_keys.explanation: Confession consists of two parts: first, **that we confess our sins**, and second, that we **receive absolution (forgiveness)** from the pastor as from God Himself. The Small Catechism teaches that the penitent should **in no wise doubt**, but firmly believe that sins are forgiven before God in heaven through this act. While we should plead guilty of all sins before God—even those we don't perceive—we should only **confess those sins to the pastor** that we know and feel in our hearts. Luther emphasizes that confession is retained **for the sake of the absolution**, which he describes as a 'great and wonderful treasure'.

questions.question: What are the two parts of Confession in the Lutheran tradition?
options: Penance and satisfaction
Confessing sins and receiving absolution
Sorrow and doing good works
Reading Scripture and prayer
questions.answer: Confessing sins and receiving absolution

questions.question: According to the Small Catechism, what sins should we confess to the pastor?
options: Every single sin we have ever committed
Only those sins our parents know about
Only those we know and feel in our hearts
None; we only confess to God
questions.answer: Only those we know and feel in our hearts

confession_and_office_of_the_keys.title: The Office of the Keys
confession_and_office_of_the_keys.explanation: The Office of the Keys is the **special authority which Christ has given to His Church** to forgive the sins of repentant sinners and withhold forgiveness from the unrepentant. Its foundation is **<bible-ref>John 20:22-23</bible-ref>**, where the risen Lord breathed on His disciples and commanded them to remit and retain sins. The Book of Concord clarifies that this power belongs **principally and immediately to the whole Church**, which then calls ministers to exercise it publicly. Lutheran teaching insists that the pastor's absolution is as **valid and certain in heaven** as if Christ our dear Lord dealt with us Himself.

questions.question: Which scriptural passage is the primary 'word of institution' for the Office of the Keys?
options: Genesis 1:1
1 Corinthians 13:1
Revelation 22:20

questions.question: How certain should a Christian be of the absolution spoken by a called minister?
options: As certain as if Christ spoke it Himself
Somewhat certain, depending on the pastor's holiness
It is merely a hopeful wish
Only as certain as their own level of contrition
questions.answer: As certain as if Christ spoke it Himself

sacrament_of_the_altar.title: Sacrament of the Altar - What is it?
sacrament_of_the_altar.explanation: It is the **true body and blood of our Lord Jesus Christ**, under the bread and wine, given to Christians to eat and drink. It was **instituted by Christ Himself**, as recorded by the Evangelists and St. Paul. The Large Catechism stresses that it is the **Word of Christ** that makes and distinguishes this sacrament from mere bread and wine. Luther famously stated that even if a 'knave' or wicked priest administers it, the recipient still receives the **true Sacrament** because it is founded on God's Word, not human holiness.

questions.question: What is received 'in, with, and under' the bread and wine?
options: A symbol of Christ's love
The true body and blood of Christ
The Holy Spirit only
The merits of the saints
questions.answer: The true body and blood of Christ

questions.question: What determines the validity of the Sacrament according to the Large Catechism?
options: The faith of the communicant
The holiness of the priest
The Word and ordinance of God
The quality of the elements
questions.answer: The Word and ordinance of God

sacrament_of_the_altar.title: Sacrament of the Altar - The Benefit
sacrament_of_the_altar.explanation: The benefits are revealed in the words **'Given and shed for you for the forgiveness of sins.'** In the Sacrament, **forgiveness of sins, life, and salvation** are delivered through these words. Luther calls it a **'daily pasture'** and a **'food of souls'** meant to strengthen the 'new man' against the constant temptations of the devil and the world. Where there is forgiveness of sins, there is also life and salvation; thus the Sacrament provides **assurance against death and every calamity**.

questions.question: What are the three core benefits given in the Sacrament of the Altar?
options: Wealth, health, and prosperity
Forgiveness, life, and salvation
Friendship, unity, and social standing
Knowledge, wisdom, and power
questions.answer: Forgiveness, life, and salvation

questions.question: Why is the Sacrament referred to as a 'precious antidote'?
options: It cures physical diseases
It acts against the 'poison' of sin in our system
It prevents the believer from ever sinning again
It makes the believer physically immortal instantly
questions.answer: It acts against the 'poison' of sin in our system

sacrament_of_the_altar.title: Sacrament of the Altar - The Power
sacrament_of_the_altar.explanation: The physical act of eating and drinking does not produce these effects; rather, the **Word of God**—specifically the phrase 'given and shed for you for the forgiveness of sins'—is the **chief thing in the Sacrament**. The Word is the **effective cause** that makes the elements the vehicle of Christ's body and blood. The Formula of Concord explains that the words of institution are **creative and powerful**, carrying the efficacy of the first Supper to every celebration today.

questions.question: What does the Small Catechism identify as the 'main thing' in the Sacrament?
options: The act of kneeling
The specific type of wine used
The words 'Given and shed for you...'
The presence of the congregation
questions.answer: The words 'Given and shed for you...'

questions.question: To what does the Formula of Concord ascribe the true presence of Christ?
options: The faith of the believers
The almighty power of God and Christ's Word
The prayer of the people
The physical breaking of the bread
questions.answer: The almighty power of God and Christ's Word

sacrament_of_the_altar.title: Sacrament of the Altar - Worthiness
sacrament_of_the_altar.explanation: True worthiness is not found in outward preparation, such as fasting, but in **faith in Christ's words: 'Given and shed for you.'** He who believes these words has exactly what they say: the forgiveness of sins. Conversely, anyone who **doubts or does not believe** these words is unworthy and unprepared, for the words 'for you' require **truly believing hearts**. The Sacrament is intended for **terrified consciences** and those who feel their weakness and need of God's grace.

questions.question: Who is 'truly worthy and well-prepared' to receive the Sacrament?
options: He who has not sinned for a week
He who has fasted since midnight
He who has faith in Christ's words 'for you'
He who can recite the entire Catechism
questions.answer: He who has faith in Christ's words 'for you'

questions.question: What is the result for those who eat and drink unworthily (without faith)?
options: They receive no body or blood at all
They receive a symbolic blessing
They eat and drink judgment to themselves
They are automatically forgiven anyway
questions.answer: They eat and drink judgment to themselves

daily_prayers.title: Morning Prayer
daily_prayers.explanation: The Christian begins the day by making the **sign of the holy cross** and saying the name of the **Triune God**. After reciting the **Creed and the Lord's Prayer**, Luther's Morning Prayer is spoken. It gives thanks to God for **gracious protection through the night** and asks Him to keep the believer from **sin and every evil** throughout the day. It concludes with the petition that God's **holy angel** be with the believer so that the wicked foe may have no power over them.

questions.question: What is the first act recommended in Luther's Morning Prayer?
options: Reading a newspaper
Making the sign of the holy cross
Singing a secular song
Planning the day's work
questions.answer: Making the sign of the holy cross

questions.question: In the Morning Prayer, what is the purpose of asking for God's holy angel?
options: To gain secret knowledge
To ensure financial success
So that the wicked foe has no power over the believer
To help with physical chores
questions.answer: So that the wicked foe has no power over the believer

daily_prayers.title: Evening Prayer
daily_prayers.explanation: At the close of the day, the Christian again makes the **sign of the cross** and recites the **Creed and Lord's Prayer**. The Evening Prayer thanks God for His **gracious protection during the day** and asks for the **forgiveness of all sins**. Like the morning prayer, it asks for the presence of the **holy angel** for protection against the devil. This ritual acts as a **daily return to one's baptism**, finding rest in God's mercy before sleep.

questions.question: What does the believer specifically ask God to forgive in the Evening Prayer?
options: Only the sins of others
All sins where they have done wrong
Only the 'big' sins
Nothing; the prayer is only for thanks
questions.answer: All sins where they have done wrong

questions.question: The Evening Prayer is described in the sources as a daily return to what?
options: The Ten Commandments
The local congregation
One's Baptism
The Garden of Eden
questions.answer: One's Baptism

daily_prayers.title: Asking a Blessing
daily_prayers.explanation: Before eating, the household gathers and recites **<bible-ref>Psalm 145:15-16</bible-ref>**, acknowledging that God gives food to all creatures in due season. The prayer follows: **'Lord God, heavenly Father, bless us and these Your gifts'**. This practice emphasizes that even physical food is a gift from **God's bountiful goodness** and is to be received with prayer and thanksgiving, recognizing God as the **Provider of all daily bread**.

questions.question: Which Psalm is traditionally used when asking a blessing before a meal?
options: Psalm 23
Psalm 51
Psalm 145
Psalm 150
questions.answer: Psalm 145

questions.question: What is the focus of the blessing before a meal?
options: Asking for more food
Recognising the food as a gift from God's bountiful goodness
Praying for the cook's skills
Demanding better quality elements
questions.answer: Recognising the food as a gift from God's bountiful goodness

daily_prayers.title: Returning Thanks
daily_prayers.explanation: After the meal, the family gives thanks, often using **<bible-ref>Psalm 136:1</bible-ref>**: **'Give thanks to the Lord, for He is good; His love endures forever'**. This prayer acknowledges that God **provides food for every creature** and expresses gratitude for His mercy. It serves as a practical application of the **First Article of the Creed**, confessing that God is the Creator who richly and daily provides all that we need for body and life.

questions.question: What attribute of God is highlighted in the prayer after a meal?
options: His wrath against sin
His distance from creation
His goodness and enduring love
His demand for payment
questions.answer: His goodness and enduring love

questions.question: Which article of the Creed does returning thanks after a meal reinforce?
options: The First Article (Creation)
The Second Article (Redemption)
The Third Article (Sanctification)
None of the articles
questions.answer: The First Article (Creation)

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Bishops, Pastors, and Preachers
table_of_duties.explanation: A **bishop or pastor must be blameless**, the husband of one wife, vigilant, sober, and of good behavior. He is to be **given to hospitality and apt to teach**, ensuring he is not a brawler or greedy for money. He must rule his own house well, keeping his children in subjection, for if he cannot manage his family, he cannot care for the Church of God. Crucially, he must **hold fast the faithful Word** as he has been taught, so that he may use sound doctrine to exhort and convince those who contradict it (<bible-ref>1 Timothy 3:2-7</bible-ref>; <bible-ref>Titus 1:6-9</bible-ref>).

questions.question: Which of the following is a specific requirement for a bishop according to the Table of Duties?
options: He must be a skilled administrator in secular business
He must be apt to teach and hold fast the faithful Word
He must never have been married
He must be a novice in the faith
questions.answer: He must be apt to teach and hold fast the faithful Word

questions.question: Why is a pastor expected to rule his own house well?
options: To demonstrate his personal wealth
To prove he can manage the Church of God
To satisfy the requirements of the civil government
To provide a place for guests to stay
questions.answer: To prove he can manage the Church of God

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: What the Hearers Owe to Their Pastors
table_of_duties.explanation: The Lord has ordained that those who **preach the Gospel should live of the Gospel** (<bible-ref>1 Corinthians 9:14</bible-ref>). Hearers are commanded to **communicate in all good things** with their teachers (<bible-ref>Galatians 6:6</bible-ref>) and to count elders who rule well worthy of **double honor**, especially those who labor in Word and doctrine (<bible-ref>1 Timothy 5:17-18</bible-ref>). This includes **obeying and submitting** to them, as they watch for souls and must give an account to God (<bible-ref>Hebrews 13:17</bible-ref>). The goal is for them to do their work with **joy and not with grief**, as the latter is unprofitable for the congregation.

questions.question: What does the Scripture mean by 'double honor' for those who labor in the Word?
options: They should receive two titles
They should be given liberal support and respect
They should be exempt from all laws
They should be served by the congregation as kings
questions.answer: They should be given liberal support and respect

questions.question: Why should hearers obey their leaders according to Hebrews 13:17?
options: Because the leaders are infallible
Because they watch for souls as those who must give an account
To ensure the pastor never feels sad
To follow a democratic vote
questions.answer: Because they watch for souls as those who must give an account

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: Concerning Civil Government
table_of_duties.explanation: Every soul is to be **subject to the higher powers**, for all authority that exists is **ordained of God** (<bible-ref>Romans 13:1</bible-ref>). The civil ruler is described as **God's minister** for the good of the citizens. The government is given the **power of the sword** to act as a revenger and execute wrath upon those who do evil (<bible-ref>Romans 13:4</bible-ref>). Resisting the power of the state is viewed as **resisting the ordinance of God**, which brings damnation upon the resistor (<bible-ref>Romans 13:2</bible-ref>).

questions.question: What is the primary role of the civil magistrate according to Romans 13?
options: To teach the Gospel to all nations
To be God's minister for the punishment of evildoers
To manage the funds of the local church
To interpret the Scriptures for the laity
questions.answer: To be God's minister for the punishment of evildoers

questions.question: From where does civil authority derive its power?
options: The common consent of the people
The military strength of the ruler
It is ordained of God
The decisions of church councils
questions.answer: It is ordained of God

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: What Subjects Owe to the Magistrates
table_of_duties.explanation: Citizens are commanded to **render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's** (<bible-ref>Matthew 22:21</bible-ref>), which includes paying **tribute, custom, and taxes** (<bible-ref>Romans 13:6-7</bible-ref>). Subjection to authorities is a matter of **conscience** (<bible-ref>Romans 13:5</bible-ref>), not just a fear of punishment. Christians are encouraged to offer **supplications, prayers, and thanksgivings** for all in authority (<bible-ref>1 Timothy 2:1-2</bible-ref>) so that society may lead a quiet and peaceable life in all godliness. In all matters, they are to **honor the king** (<bible-ref>1 Peter 2:17</bible-ref>) and governors as those sent for the praise of them that do well (<bible-ref>1 Peter 2:13-14</bible-ref>).

questions.question: Why does the Small Catechism say citizens should be subject to government?
options: Only because they fear physical punishment
Not only for wrath, but also for conscience' sake
To gain a higher standing in the Church
Because the government provides the Means of Grace
questions.answer: Not only for wrath, but also for conscience' sake

questions.question: What specific act should Christians perform for their rulers according to 1 Timothy 2:1-2?
options: Build monuments to them
Offer prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings
Vote for them in every election
Invite them to preach in the church
questions.answer: Offer prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Husbands
table_of_duties.explanation: Husbands are to **dwell with their wives according to knowledge**, giving **honor to the wife as the weaker vessel**. They are reminded that they are **heirs together of the grace of life**, and they are warned that if they fail in this duty, their **prayers will be hindered** (<bible-ref>1 Peter 3:7</bible-ref>). Furthermore, they are commanded to **love their wives** as Christ loved the Church (<bible-ref>Ephesians 5:25</bible-ref>) and to **never be bitter** against them (<bible-ref>Colossians 3:19</bible-ref>).

questions.question: What is the consequence of a husband not honoring his wife?
options: He will lose his job
His prayers will be hindered
He must pay a fine to the church
He is no longer a citizen
questions.answer: His prayers will be hindered

questions.question: What is the model for a husband's love according to Ephesians 5?
options: The love of parents for children
How Christ loved the Church and gave Himself for it
The mutual agreement of friends
The pursuit of personal happiness
questions.answer: How Christ loved the Church and gave Himself for it

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Wives
table_of_duties.explanation: Wives are exhorted to **submit themselves to their own husbands as unto the Lord** (<bible-ref>Ephesians 5:22</bible-ref>). This submission is modeled after **Sarah**, who obeyed Abraham and called him 'lord' (<bible-ref>1 Peter 3:5-6</bible-ref>). Wives are encouraged to maintain a **chaste conversation** and the ornament of a **meek and quiet spirit**, which is of great price in the sight of God. This subjection is to be done 'in the Lord', acknowledging the husband as the head of the wife just as Christ is the head of the Church.

questions.question: Who is presented as a biblical model for wives in the Table of Duties?
options: Mary Magdalene
Sarah
Ruth
Deborah
questions.answer: Sarah

questions.question: According to the sources, what is of 'great price' in the sight of God for a wife?
options: Expensive apparel and gold jewelry
A meek and quiet spirit
A successful career outside the home
Superiority over her husband
questions.answer: A meek and quiet spirit

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Parents
table_of_duties.explanation: Fathers are specifically commanded **not to provoke their children to wrath**. Instead of being harsh or overbearing, they are to **bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord** (<bible-ref>Ephesians 6:4</bible-ref>). This involves providing for both the bodily and spiritual needs of the children, acting as 'bishop' and 'bishopress' in the home to ensure the children learn the fear and knowledge of God.

questions.question: What are parents forbidden from doing to their children?
options: Sending them to school
Provoking them to wrath
Giving them household chores
Teaching them the Catechism
questions.answer: Provoking them to wrath

questions.question: What is the positive duty of parents mentioned in the Table of Duties?
options: To amass a great inheritance for their children
To bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord
To allow children to choose their own religion
To ensure children never suffer any hardship
questions.answer: To bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Children
table_of_duties.explanation: Children are commanded to **obey their parents in the Lord**, for this is right. They are to **honor their father and mother**, which is the first commandment with a promise: that it may be **well with them** and they may **live long on the earth** (<bible-ref>Ephesians 6:1-3</bible-ref>). This obedience is seen as a holy and precious work in the sight of God, far surpassing self-chosen religious works.

questions.question: What is the promise attached to the commandment to honor parents?
options: That they will become rich
That it may be well with them and they may live long on the earth
That they will never face temptation
That they will become leaders in the Church
questions.answer: That it may be well with them and they may live long on the earth

questions.question: Why is a child's obedience considered a 'golden work'?
options: Because it is difficult to do
Because it is commanded by God
Because it earns salvation
Because it makes parents happy
questions.answer: Because it is commanded by God

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Male and Female Servants, Hired Men, and Laborers
table_of_duties.explanation: Servants and laborers are to be **obedient to their masters** with fear, trembling, and **singleness of heart**, as unto Christ. They should work **not with eye-service as men-pleasers**, but as the servants of Christ, doing the **will of God from the heart** (<bible-ref>Ephesians 6:5-7</bible-ref>). They are promised that whatever good thing they do, they will **receive the same from the Lord**, regardless of their status as bond or free (<bible-ref>Ephesians 6:8</bible-ref>).

questions.question: How should a Christian worker perform their duties?
options: With eye-service to gain a promotion
As servants of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart
Only when the supervisor is watching
With a focus on personal profit only
questions.answer: As servants of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart

questions.question: What is the motivation for a worker to serve faithfully even under a harsh master?
options: The fear of the executioner
The promise that they will receive a reward from the Lord
To earn their freedom immediately
To prove they are better than their master
questions.answer: The promise that they will receive a reward from the Lord

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Masters and Mistresses
table_of_duties.explanation: Masters are to do the **same things** toward their workers, **forbearing threatening**. They must remember that they also have a **Master in heaven**, and that there is **no respect of persons with Him** (<bible-ref>Ephesians 6:9</bible-ref>; <bible-ref>Colossians 4:1</bible-ref>). This requires them to treat their servants with **justice and equality**, recognizing that in God's eyes, both master and servant stand on a common ground of need and grace.

questions.question: What are masters specifically commanded to 'forbear'?
options: Paying wages
Threatening
Providing food
Teaching the Word
questions.answer: Threatening

questions.question: What should a master always keep in mind regarding his own status?
options: He is the ultimate authority in his house
He also has a Master in heaven with whom there is no partiality
He is superior to his servants in every way
His wealth is proof of his holiness
questions.answer: He also has a Master in heaven with whom there is no partiality

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Young Persons in General
table_of_duties.explanation: Young people are to **submit themselves to the elder** and be clothed with **humility**, for God resists the proud but gives **grace to the humble** (<bible-ref>1 Peter 5:5-6</bible-ref>).

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For Widows
table_of_duties.explanation: **Widows** who are 'widows indeed' are to trust in God and continue in **supplications and prayers** night and day (<bible-ref>1 Timothy 5:5-6</bible-ref>).

questions.question: What is the duty of a 'widow indeed'?
options: To remarry as quickly as possible
To live in pleasure
To trust in God and continue in prayer
To become a judge in the church
questions.answer: To trust in God and continue in prayer

table_of_duties.title: Table of Duties: For All in Common
table_of_duties.explanation: **Everyone** is bound by the summary commandment: **'Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself.'** All other duties and commandments are briefly comprehended in this one rule of love (<bible-ref>Romans 13:8-10</bible-ref>; <bible-ref>1 Timothy 2:1</bible-ref>).

questions.question: What is the summary of all 'Relative Duties' to one's neighbor?
options: To gain as much property as possible
To love thy neighbor as thyself
To follow only the first three commandments
To avoid all social contact
questions.answer: To love thy neighbor as thyself

christian_questions_and_answers.title: Christian Questions with Their Answers
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: These questions are designed to move the catechumen from a knowledge of their own sin to the **absolute certainty of forgiveness** in Christ. By focusing on the **external Word and promise**, the Small Catechism provides the 'most certain' foundation for the life of the baptized. Outside of this framework of Law and Gospel, the Sacrament can be easily misunderstood as a human work rather than a **divine gift**.

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: Do you believe that you are a sinner?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: A Christian must begin by **confessing their status as a sinner**, acknowledging that they have offended God. This is not a mere intellectual admission but a realization that permeates the heart of the believer.

questions.question: What is the primary belief required before receiving the Sacrament?
options: That you have done enough good works
That you are a sinner
That you have mastered the Small Catechism
That you are physically healthy
questions.answer: That you are a sinner

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: How do you know this?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The knowledge of sin is derived specifically from the **Ten Commandments**, which the individual recognizes they have not kept. The Law serves as a mirror to reveal the depth of human corruption.

questions.question: According to the sources, what tool reveals that a person is a sinner?
options: Human reason and logic
The Ten Commandments
Personal feelings of guilt
The opinions of neighbors
questions.answer: The Ten Commandments

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: Are you sorry for your sins?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: True repentance involves being **genuinely sorry** for having sinned against God. This sorrow is a sacrifice with which God is pleased, as seen in the example of King David (<bible-ref>Psalm 51:17</bible-ref>).

questions.question: What characterizes the heart of a person rightly prepared for the Sacrament?
options: Happiness and celebration only
Sorrow for having sinned against God
A sense of moral superiority
Indifference to past mistakes
questions.answer: Sorrow for having sinned against God

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: What have you deserved from God because of your sins?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The Law teaches that sin deserves God's **wrath and displeasure, temporal death, and eternal damnation** (<bible-ref>Romans 6:23</bible-ref>). This realization is necessary to understand the magnitude of the grace offered in the Gospel.

questions.question: What are the consequences of sin according to the Small Catechism?
options: Minor social embarrassment
Temporary setbacks in life
Wrath, temporal death, and eternal damnation
None, because God is only love
questions.answer: Wrath, temporal death, and eternal damnation

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: Do you hope to be saved?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: Despite the deserved damnation, the Christian maintains a **steadfast hope for salvation**. This hope is not based on self-improvement but on the external promises of God.

questions.question: Upon what is the Christian's hope for salvation based?
options: Internal feelings of peace
The promises and grace of God
The performance of daily rituals
The lack of significant sins
questions.answer: The promises and grace of God

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: In whom then do you trust?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The believer places their entire confidence in their **dear Lord Jesus Christ**. Trusting in Christ is the only way to find relief from the terrors of the Law.

questions.question: Who is the object of the Christian's trust for salvation?
options: The Virgin Mary
The individual's own faith
Jesus Christ
The Church hierarchy
questions.answer: Jesus Christ

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: Who is Christ?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: Christ is confessed as the **Son of God, true God and true man** in one person. His two natures are essential for his role as the Redeemer of the world.

questions.question: What are the two natures of Jesus Christ?
options: Spirit and flesh only
True God and true man
Prophet and King only
Angel and human
questions.answer: True God and true man

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: How many Gods are there?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: There is **only one God**, but he exists in **three persons**: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. This Trinitarian confession distinguishes Christian worship from all other religions.

questions.question: How many persons exist in the one Godhead?
options: One
Two
Three
Twelve
questions.answer: Three

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: What has Christ done for you that you trust in Him?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: Christ **died and shed His blood** on the cross for the **forgiveness of sins**. This objective act of redemption is the sole ground for the believer's justification.

questions.question: What specific act of Christ provides the basis for trust in Him?
options: His teaching of the Sermon on the Mount
His birth in Bethlehem
His death and the shedding of His blood
His performance of many miracles
questions.answer: His death and the shedding of His blood

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: Did the Father also die for you?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The Father did not die, as He is **God only**; the Son alone is both **true God and true man** who suffered and died. This maintains the biblical distinction between the persons of the Trinity.

questions.question: Why did the Father not die for the sins of the world?
options: He was not willing to suffer
He is God only and did not take on human nature
He died first before the Son
The Holy Spirit died instead
questions.answer: He is God only and did not take on human nature

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: How do you know this?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: This truth is known from the **Holy Gospel**, the words of the **Sacrament**, and the physical **pledge of His body and blood**. These external means provide the certainty that faith requires.

questions.question: What serves as a 'pledge' of Christ's work for the believer?
options: The feeling of peace in the heart
The physical body and blood given in the Sacrament
A successful and prosperous life
The authority of the Pope
questions.answer: The physical body and blood given in the Sacrament

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: What are the Words of Institution?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The Words of Institution are the **authoritative command of Christ** regarding the bread and the cup, emphasizing the **remission of sins**. These words are the 'effective cause' that makes the Sacrament what it is.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of the Sacrament mentioned in the Words of Institution?
options: Social unity among members
The forgiveness of sins
A reminder of ancient history
A symbolic representation of love
questions.answer: The forgiveness of sins

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: Do you believe, then, that the true body and blood of Christ are in the Sacrament?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The Christian confesses the **real and essential presence** of Christ's body and blood 'in, with, and under' the elements. This belief is founded on the **Word and ordinance of God**, not human holiness.

questions.question: Upon what is the validity of the body and blood in the Sacrament founded?
options: The faith of the communicant
The holiness of the presiding minister
The Word and ordinance of God
The quality of the bread and wine
questions.answer: The Word and ordinance of God

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: What convinces you to believe this?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The believer is convinced by the **words of Christ**: 'Take, eat, this is My body; drink of it, all of you, this is My blood'. These are **creative and powerful words** that carry the efficacy of the first Supper to today.

questions.question: What does the Formula of Concord describe as the power making Christ present?
options: The prayer of the people
The creative and powerful words of Christ
The manual acts of the priest
The atmosphere of the sanctuary
questions.answer: The creative and powerful words of Christ

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: What should we do when we eat His body and drink His blood, and in this way receive His pledge?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: When we eat and drink, we are to **believe the words** of Christ and remember His death. By believing the words 'given and shed for you,' the communicant **receives the forgiveness of sins**.

questions.question: How is the promise of the Sacrament received by the individual?
options: Through the physical act of chewing and swallowing
Through faith in the words 'for you'
Through a public display of piety
Through the mediation of the saints
questions.answer: Through faith in the words 'for you'

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: Why should we want to go to the Sacrament often?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: We should go frequently to **remember Christ's death** and to have our **faith strengthened** against sin and the devil. The Sacrament serves as a **'daily pasture'** to nourish the new man in the face of constant trial.

questions.question: Why is the Sacrament described as a 'daily pasture' for the soul?
options: Because it is a social tradition
Because it strengthens the believer against temptation
Because it is a simple meal of bread and wine
Because it represents the beauty of nature
questions.answer: Because it strengthens the believer against temptation

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: What should a person do if they feel their faith is weak or they have a troubled conscience?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The Sacrament is intended precisely for **terrified consciences** and those who feel their weakness. They are encouraged to seek the **comfort and strength** found at the Lord's Table.

questions.question: For whom is the Lord's Supper especially intended?
options: Those who have achieved perfect holiness
Those with terrified consciences and weak faith
Those who can explain complex theological systems
Those who have not sinned for several weeks
questions.answer: Those with terrified consciences and weak faith

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: What if you find yourself unworthy or unprepared?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: Worthiness is not found in outward preparation or fasting, but in **faith in Christ's words**. Faith lives on the **external promises** that provide a 'most certain theology'.

questions.question: What defines true 'worthiness' to receive the Sacrament?
options: Fasting since the previous midnight
Faith in Christ's words 'Given and shed for you'
A high level of emotional excitement
The ability to memorize the entire Bible
questions.answer: Faith in Christ's words 'Given and shed for you'

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: How can eating and drinking do such great things?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The physical act does not produce forgiveness; rather, the **Word of God** connected to the eating and drinking is the 'chief thing'. The Word is the **effective cause** that delivers life and salvation.

questions.question: What is the 'chief thing' in the Sacrament that delivers the benefits?
options: The chemical properties of the elements
The physical act of eating
The Word of God
The congregation's unity
questions.answer: The Word of God

christian_questions_and_answers.question_text: But what should you do if you are not aware of this need and have no hunger and thirst for the Sacrament?
christian_questions_and_answers.explanation: The sources suggest three physical and spiritual checks: **touch your body** to see if you are still flesh and blood (<bible-ref>Galatians 5:19-21</bible-ref>; <bible-ref>Romans 7:18</bible-ref>); **look at the world** to see its sin and trouble (<bible-ref>John 15:18-19</bible-ref>; <bible-ref>1 John 2:15-17</bible-ref>); and **remember the devil** who seeks to murder the soul (<bible-ref>1 Peter 5:8-9</bible-ref>). These realities drive a person to seek the **strength of the Sacrament**.

questions.question: What is the advice for those who lack hunger for the Lord's Supper?
options: Wait until they feel more holy
Read a secular self-help book
Touch their body to see if they are still 'flesh and blood'
Stop attending church for a season
questions.answer: Touch their body to see if they are still 'flesh and blood'

questions.question: According to Question 20, what three things should a person consider if they are indifferent to the Sacrament?
options: Their health, their wealth, and their fame
Their body, the world, and the devil
Their parents, their children, and their spouse
Their logic, their reason, and their intellect
questions.answer: Their body, the world, and the devil
